reasoning: First off, Amazon doesn’t fall inside my circle of competence. I’ve spent my life studying simple businesses that produce tangible goods and services – think See’s Candies, Coca-Cola or Apple’s consumer ecosystem – not sprawling e-commerce marketplaces and capital-intensive cloud platforms. While Amazon has built a strong brand and network effects around Prime and AWS, its ROE has been negative over the past year and uneven across cycles, so I can’t point to a durable, predictable moat the way I can with a business like Coca-Cola’s beverage franchise. Management earned my respect by reinvesting heavily in growth, but I prefer executives who allocate capital conservatively and reward shareholders with dividends or buybacks once the reinvestment opportunities reach diminishing returns. Amazon’s free cash flow hasn’t been consistent enough, and the company still plows almost everything back into capex, leaving little clarity on long-term capital discipline. From a financial health standpoint, upside from AWS margins is attractive, but overall earnings and ROE remain choppy, and there’s no margin of safety here. At roughly a $1.65 trillion market cap versus an intrinsic value near $142 per share, you’re effectively paying about double what I’d consider fair. I’d rather own wonderful businesses in my wheelhouse trading at sensible prices than a complex, opaque business at an elevated valuation. In comparison to opportunities in my portfolio – like Coca-Cola’s reliable pricing power or Apple’s sticky ecosystem – Amazon doesn’t meet my criteria on simplicity, consistency or price. So my answer here is a hard “no.”

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of -1.3%; Conservative debt levels; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 109.2% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Decent operating margins (avg: 27.6%) suggest some competitive advantage

book_value_analysis.details: Good book value per share growth pattern

management_analysis.details: No significant new stock issuance detected; No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (3.0%, 5y), Stage 2 (1.5%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
